editionStmt.funder: Conversion of the printed catalogue to TEI funded by the Warden and Fellows of Merton College .

msItem.note: On f. iii, in a rough Italian cursive hand, s. xiv, is a table of contents to I, and ‘Libri Senece’. On f. iiiv are scribbles, s. xv, including an extract from ‘quadam epistola apostrophando ad Senecam’, ‘Plutarchus siquidem grayus uester et Trayani principis doctor comparans suos Grecos ad nostros latinos ...’. f. iv is blank.

physDesc.p: Three originally separate volumes, I and II probably together soon after the making of II; III could have been added at any time between then and s. xvii or even later.

supportDesc.collation: A bifolium, 110(lacks 1), 2–1510, 166 / 17–2012, 216(4–6 canc.) / 2210; I and II have catchwords. A quire is missing after 3.

binding.p: 1963; full tan goatskin. Fols. i-ii and 218–19 are modern paper binding leaves. f. iii has the mark of a brass chain-staple near the foot of the foredge.

history.provenance: On f. iiiv ‘Iste liber operum Senece est Iohannis ex Bello Vallorum familia episcopi Andegauensis.’ John of Beauveau was bp. of Angers 1451–1479.

On f. ivvis ‘liber Collegii de Mertone in Oxon’ incatenandus in communi libraria eiusdem ad utilitatem sociorum ac aliorum studentium ibidem Ex perquisicione magistri Ricardi Fitz James nuper Custodis eiusdem. Et continentur in hoc uolumine omnia opera Senece uiri disertissimi.’ It was placed in the library on 2 Aug. 1494 (Registrum, p. 184). For Fitzjames, warden 1483–1507, see MS 9. The inscription was written at least thirteen years after the book came to the College.
On f. ivvare the James no. ‘93’, ‘Q. 2. 13. Art:’, and contents (I and II), s. xvii. ‘13’ is inked on the foredge.

source.bibl: R. M. Thomson, A descriptive catalogue of the medieval manuscripts of Merton College, Oxford (Cambridge: D. S. Brewer), 2009.

availability.p: For enquiries relating to this manuscript please contact Merton College Library.

listBibl.bibl: Coxe, pp. 119–20; Powicke, no. 1114; Alexander & Temple, nos 772, 900.

msItem.author: SENECA
msItem.title: Epist.
msItem.explicit: hoc quidem nobis reliquerunt melius scire.
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit liber Annei Lucii Senece de septem liberabus artibus.
msItem.note: Ed. L. D. Reynolds (2 vols, Oxford, 1965), I, pp. 320–3.

msItem.author: SENECA
msItem.title: Quaestiones Naturales
msItem.rubric: Incipit liber primus de questionibus naturalibus Lucii Annei Senece de diuersitate uaporum eleuatorum in altum ...
msItem.incipit: Quantum inter philosophiam inter est Lucilli nostrorum optime et ceteras artes

msItem.title: Florilegium of short moral sentences
msItem.note: For a while in roughly alphabetical order, from works by or attrib. to SENECA
msItem.incipit: (Beg. as Ps.-SENECA/ PUBLILIUS SYRUS, Prouerbia) Alienum est omne quicquid optando euenit
msItem.explicit: (SENECA, De Clement. 2. 7) Hanc sapiens quare dare non debeat reddit rationem quibus hoc diutius propositum est.

msItem.author: SENECA
msItem.title: De Prouidentia Dei
msItem.rubric: Incipit liber primus eiusdem de prouidentia Dei ad Lucillum ...
msItem.incipit: [mutil.]uesisti a me Lucili quid ita si prouidentia
msItem.explicit: (ends impf.) ideoque ex omnibus rebus quas (catchwords esse nobis)
msItem.note: Ed. L. D. Reynolds (Oxford, 1977). The table of contents shows that Dial. 2 and 7 are missing after this.

msItem.author: SENECA
msItem.title: De Tranquillitate Animi
msItem.explicit: et assidua cura circuit annum labentem.
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit liber Annei Lucii Senece de tranquillitate animi ad Serenum.

msItem.author: SENECA
msItem.title: De Brevitate Vitae
msItem.incipit: Incipit liber eiusdem de breuitate uite ad Paulinum. Maior pars mortalium Pauline de nature malignitate conqueritur

msItem.author: SENECA
msItem.title: De Ira
msItem.rubric: Incipit liber primus de Ira ad Nouatum.
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit liber tertius Annei Lucii Senece de ira ad Nouatum.

msItem.author: SENECA
msItem.title: Ad Marciam de Consolatione
msItem.rubric: Incipit liber eiusdem ad Marciam de consolatione filii sui.
msItem.incipit: Nisi te Marcia scirem tam longe ab infirmitate muliebris animi

msItem.author: SENECA
msItem.title: Ad Heluiam de Consolatione
msItem.rubric: Incipit liber eiusdem ad Herbiam matrem de consolatione. Rubrica.
msItem.incipit: Sepe iam mater optima impetum cepi consolandi te

msItem.title: Epistolae Pauli et Senecae
msItem.incipit: [mutil.]cius Ennius Seneca Cordubensis Fotini stoici discipulus
msItem.note: CPL 191; ed. L. Boccolini Palagi (Biblioteca Patrum 5: Fiesole, 1985).
Followed by the epitaph ‘Cura labor meritum sumpti pro munere honores’ (Hildebert; WIC 3960).

msItem.author: SENECA
msItem.title: Epistolae
msItem.incipit: Ita fac mi Lucilli uendica te tibi et tempus quod adhuc aut auferebat

msItem.author: Ps.-SENECA
msItem.title: De Remediis Fortuitorum
msItem.rubric: Lucii Annei Senece ad Galionem de remediis fortuitorum.
msItem.incipit: [mutil.]icet cunctorum poetarum carmina gremium nostrum semper illustrent

msItem.author: MARTIN OF BRAGA
msItem.title: Formula Honestae Vitae
msItem.incipit: Incipit libellus Senece de quatuor uirtutibus. Quatuor uirtutum species multorum sapientum sententiis diffinite sunt
msItem.note: CPL 1080; ed. C. W. Barlow, Martini Episcopi Bracarensis Opera Omnia (New Haven, Conn., 1950), pp. 236–50; Bloomfield 4457.

msItem.author: SENECA THE ELDER
msItem.title: Controuersiae
msItem.incipit: [mutil.]gistis a me rem magis auidam [pro iocundum] michi
msItem.note: Ed. H. J. Müller (Vienna, 1887); ed. L. Hakanson (Leipzig, 1989).

msItem.author: SENECA
msItem.title: De Clementia
msItem.rubric: Incipit liber Senece de clementia ad Neronem.
msItem.incipit: Scribere de clementia Nero Cesar proposui

msItem.author: SENECA
msItem.title: De Beneficiis
msItem.rubric: Incipit primus liber Senece de beneficiis.
msItem.explicit: hoc est magni animi perdere et dare.
msItem.finalRubric: Expliciunt libri Senece scripti per manus Gerardi Iohannis de Romaricomonte Tullensis dyocesia.
msItem.note: Ed. C. Hosius (Leipzig, 1914), pp. 1–209. Followed by a table of contents in red.
Annotated in a humanistic bookhand (similar to that of Florius), and in a humanistic cursive.

extent.note: Parchment prepared in the Italian manner. The edges retrimmed, affecting some decoration and marginalia, the feet and formerly foredge stained yellow. Contemporary foliation in roman numerals, often cropped, ii-clxvi.

layoutDesc.layout: Ruled with crayon in 2 cols of 64 lines.

handDesc.handNote: In the expert gothic rotunda bookhand of Gerard Iohannes, notary of Remiremont, diocese of Toul: Colophons, no. 5302 (Trier, Staatsbibl. 1345).

decoDesc.decoNote: Italian. Splendid 8–9 line initials with 1–3-sided borders in colours and gold, often mutilated, that on the original fol. 1 gone altogether: fols. 1 (Seneca in conversation with Lucilius), 5 (mutil.), 9 (sea and sky), 16 (the four winds), 18 (mutil.), 22, 25, 28 (mutil.), 31v, 37v (mutil.), 40, 44, 49, 53v, 57 (24-line, mutil.), 92v, 96, 100v, 103, 115v (mutil.), 116v, 117v (mutil.), 119v, 121, 122v, 126, 130v, 132, 133, 134v (mostly excised), 136v, 138v, 143, 146v (king with sword and buckler), 149v, 153; red initials flourished in violet, blue initials flourished in red; red or blue paraphs; red highlighting.

origin.origPlace: Hand: Gerard Iohannes, notary of Remiremont, diocese of Toul, France. Decoration: Italian.

msItem.author: SENECA
msItem.title: Tragedies
msItem.rubric: Incipiunt tragedie Senece poete tragicorum clarissimi.
msItem.incipit: Tragedia prima Herculis furentes. Soror tonantis hoc enim solum michi
msItem.finalRubric: Expliciunt tragedie Senece ... scripte per Florium. Deo gratias.
msItem.note: Ed. O. Zwierlein (Oxford, 1986). In the order Hercules Furens, Thyestes, Oedipus, Phaedra, Octauia, Oedipus (‘Iam nocte pulsa’), Hecuba, Medea, Agamemnon, Octauia (‘Iam uaga celo’), Hercules Oetheus (‘Sator deorum’).

msItem.author: SENECA
msItem.title: Apocolocyntosis
msItem.rubric: Incipit ludus Senece de morte Claudii imperatoris romanorum.
msItem.note: Ed. C. F. Russo (6th edn., Florence, 1965).

extent.note: Parchment prepared in the Italian manner.

layoutDesc.layout: Ruled with red ink in 2 cols of 60 lines.

handDesc.handNote: In the Italian gothic rotunda bookhand, influenced by humanistica, of Franciscus Florius, a Florentine scribe working in France, c. 1449–80: C. F. Finlayson, ‘Florius Infortunatus’, Scriptorium 16 (1962), 378–80; Colophons, nos 4133, 4262–4; G. Tournoy, ‘Francesco Florio's Novella revisited’, Humanistica Lovaniensia 40 (1991), 30–42, manuscripts listed at pp. 32–3. Xavier Binnebeke has recently recognized his hand in Berlin, Staatsbibliothek, Hamilton 97 (Boethius).

decoDesc.decoNote: French. On f. 157 a 6-line initial in colours and gold, on a square ground with 2-sided border; at the foot an ornament or coat of arms has been excised; champe initials open each play; plain red or blue initials and paraphs; highlighting in yellow.

msItem.title: Indexes to Seneca’s correspondence
msItem.incipit: Epistolas Senece ad Lucillum 89 duasque ad Neronem de clementia iuxta libri mei tenorem sibi intitulatas tabulaui secundum ordinem alphabeti easque omnes et singulas ut malui sub oratione breui clamque perstringens cuius quidem tabule primus numerus epistolam quotat, secundus autem partem eius monstrat quantam non equaliter partiuntur cum in quantitate sententie dicte sint equales expedit eiusdem partibus in magnitudine numerum suum diligenter anteponere. Sic eum sine tedio inueniemus quesitum
msItem.explicit: Tabula super epistolis Senece ad Lucilium ordinata Parisiis Amen.
msItem.note: The same index is in Auxerre, Bibl. mun. 82 (s. xiv), fols. 69v-74v, and 243 (AD 1358), fols. 38–45.

extent.note: The edges retrimmed, affecting some decoration and marginalia, the feet and formerly foredge stained yellow.

handDesc.handNote: French bastarda, perhaps of Bishop John of Angers.

revisionDesc.change: Sebastian Dows-Miller. Resolved typo in calendar value.
